idCitation.collTitle: MAPPING TIDAL RESTRICTIONS AND TIDAL WETLANDS TO SUPPORT IDENTIFICATION AND EVALUATION OF RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES IN PUGET SOUND

dataIdInfo.idAbs: The primary goal of this project is to support regional salmon and habitat/ecosystem recovery efforts by developing consistent and updated regional datasets for tidal restrictions, current tidal wetland extent, and potential tidal wetland extent; and to make these datasets readily available online to support tidal restriction removal planning and the restoration and conservation of tidal wetland habitats in Puget Sound’s large river deltas. Regional datasets used to inform the data inventory, contract information, and related documents can be found: https://secure.rco.wa.gov/prism/search/projectsnapshot.aspx?ProjectNumber=18-2250
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The Tidal Wetland network represents the current and potential tidal wetland habitat network as polygons and their tidal connectivity determined using the Tidal Restriction network, remotely sensed aerial imagery, SHSTMP tidal wetland habitat extent and feature polygons (NOAA 2011; 2016), and Pacific Marine and Estuarine Fish Habitat Partnership (PMEP) tidal exceedance polygons (PMEP 2018). The maps of current and potential tidal wetland habitat were updated using the spatial database of the tidal restriction network developed in this project, SHSTMP tidal wetland habitat extent, feature polygons, and overwater structures (NOAA 2011; 2016; 2019), and Pacific Marine and Estuarine Fish Habitat Partnership (PMEP) tidal exceedance polygons (PMEP 2018). Tidal restrictions were buffered and used to segment PMEP wetland polygons into individual polygons, to associate tidal restriction features, feature types, and tidal connectivity ratings to polygons of tidal wetland habitat. Tidal wetland connectivity ratings were determined using the Tidal Restriction network and the SHSTMP tidal wetland habitat features to assess pathways of tidal movement and were assigned as Completely Restricted, Significantly Restricted, Partially Restricted, Unrestricted, or Unknown. Tidal wetlands were classified by both their tidal feature connectivity and landscape connectivity with certainty ratings. The feature tidal connectivity classified the tidal connectivity of the feature based on the tidal connectivity to that feature given the immediately downstream tidal restriction features. Feature tidal connectivity was determined by the downstream feature allowing tidal connectivity regardless of upstream or landward tidal restrictions connectivity restrictions. The landscape tidal connectivity classified the tidal connectivity of the wetland feature based on its connectivity to the delta as a whole. The landscape tidal connectivity of a feature was determined by the connectivity rating of the landscape wetlands and the downstream tidal restriction features.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
These data were digitized by staff at Cramer Fish Sciences as part of an Estuary and Salmon Restoration Program (ESRP) Learning Project to provide updated maps of current and potential tidal wetland habitats that will be used to evaluate estuary restoration effectiveness in a subset of Puget Sound’s large river deltas. These layers were created starting in Fall 2019 and were completed Summer 2021.
This project is part of a joint effort, involving National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Salmon Habitat Status and Trends Monitoring Program (SHSTMP; Beechie et al. 2017; Stefankiv et al. 2019), Puget Sound Partnership’s (PSP) Common Indicators, and Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife’s (WDFW) Fish Passage teams.
Any comments on data quality and determinations should be directed to Cramer Fish Sciences Staff: Jason Hall, Jason.Hall@fishsciences.net or Shelby Burgess, Shelby.Burgess@fishsciences.net.

Consts.useLimit: These data were generated using the available imagery and regional data and may not represent changes that have occurred since the publication date of the image or regional data. Only a subset of feature existence, type, connectivity, and other determinations have not been subject to regional data steward review or field verification. Physical characteristics, including areas and perimeters of tidal restriction and wetland features were generated using GIS analysis and may not be accurate. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations

LegConsts.useLimit: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
LegConsts.othConsts: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.

aggrDSName.resTitle: MAPPING TIDAL RESTRICTIONS AND TIDAL WETLANDS TO SUPPORT IDENTIFICATION AND EVALUATION OF RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES IN PUGET SOUND

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: This dataset was created on a 64-bit machine with Intel Core i7-5600U, 2.60GHz, utilizing QGIS version 3.10.0 Coruña

report.measDesc: Metadata matches attribute table: Yes Values within ranges: Yes Duplicated Data: No geometry report/repair: Yes
Data represent tidal restrictions and wetlands in the Puget Sound large river deltas.

prcStep.stepDesc:
(1) Digitizing tidal wetland areas a. Objective. To map current and potential tidal wetland extents for the Puget Sound large river deltas using mapped tidal restriction networks to determine connectivity and area. b. Study area. The PMEP Estuary Extent was used as the expected range of tidal influence and informed the potential and current wetland extent based on current topography. PMEP Estuary Extent was clipped to SHSTMP delta boundaries (NOAA 2016) for each large river delta and served as the potential wetland extent for each delta. c. Set up wetlands • QGIS I. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Clip Input layer: PMEP Tidal Wetlands and Estuary Extent Overlay layer: SHSTMP Delta Boundaries Output layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip II. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Difference Input layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip Overlay layer: Puget Sound Developed Polygons Output layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip_NoDev • ARCGIS I. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Clip Input Features: PMEP Tidal Wetlands and Estuary Extent Clip Features: SHSTMP Delta Boundaries Output Features: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip II. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Symmetrical Difference Input Features: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip Overlay layer: Puget Sound Developed Polygons Output layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip_NoDev (2) Buffer tidal restriction network a. Objective. Buffer tidal restrictions by the average width of restriction features to segment tidal wetlands. • QGIS I. [Digitizing Toolbar]> Buffer Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Restriction Mapping 1. Distance= 10 feet 2. Segments= 5 3. End cap style= Round 4. Join style= Round 5. Miter limit= 2.0 6. Dissolve result Output layer: Restrictions_buffered • ARCGIS II. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Buffer Input feature: Puget Sound Tidal Restriction Mapping 1. Distance = 10 feet 2. Side Type= Full 3. End Type= Round 4. Method= Planar 5. Dissolve Type = Dissolve all output features into a single feature Output Feature Class: Restrictions_buffered (3) Segmenting wetlands using tidal restriction buffers a. Objective. Use buffered tidal restrictions to segment PMEP tidal estuary extent into wetland polygons attributed with connectivity ratings determined by tidal restrictions. • QGIS I. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Difference Input layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip_NoDev Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered >Wetlands_multipart II. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Multipart to singleparts >Wetlands_singleparts III. Select all Wetlands_singleparts features IV. [Edit]> Copy Features V. Puget Sound Wetlands template layer>Toggle editing>[Edit]>Paste Features Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_working • ARCGIS I. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Symmetrical Difference Input layer: PMEP_SHSTMP_clip_NoDev Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered >Wetlands_multipart II. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Multipart to singlepart >Wetlands_singleparts III. Select all features IV. [Edit]> Copy Features V. Puget Sound Wetlands template feature layer>[Create Features Window] Select polygon to edit>Paste features Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_working (4) Attribute tidal wetland features with Distributary networks a. Objective. Attribute tidal wetland features with distributary networks from SHSTMP data layers (NOAA 2011). • QGIS I. Saved all Distributary features in SHSTMP_PS_Delta_Habitat_Features_2011> SHSTMP_PS_Delta_Habitat_Features_2011_Distributary II. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Fix Geometries III. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Difference Input layer: Fix geometries Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered IV. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Vector Overlay>Union Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_working Overlay layer: Difference VI. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Multipart to singleparts >Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels VII. Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels > Toggle editing a. Deleted all features not in the delta of interest b. Use the attributed data to label all Distributary features as such in column F_Type c. Delete all columns added as a result of the Union d. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Fix Geometries e. FID column >$id f. Measure tool> to label all features adjacent to the distributary network but less than the distributary width in width as “Fringe Wetlands” Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels • ARCGIS I. Saved all Distributary features in SHSTMP_PS_Delta_Habitat_Features_2011> SHSTMP_PS_Delta_Habitat_Features_2011_Distributary II. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Repair Geometry III. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Symmetrical Difference Input layer: Repair Geometry Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered VIII. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Union Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_working Overlay layer: Difference IX. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Multipart to singlepart >Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels X. Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels >[Editor Toolbar]>Create Features a. Deleted all features not in the delta of interest b. Use the attributed data to label all Distributary features as such in column F_Type c. Delete all columns added as a result of the Union d. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Repair Geometry e. FID column >$id f. Measure tool> to label all features adjacent to the distributary network but less than the distributary width in width as “Fringe Wetlands” Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels (5) Attribute tidal wetland features with Overwater Structures a. Objective. Attribute tidal wetland features with overwater pier and dock structures from SHSTMP data layers (NOAA 2019). • QGIS I. Saved all Overwater Pier and Dock features in SHSTMP_PS_Marine_Over_Water_Structures_2018> SHSTMP_PS_Marine_Over_Water_Structures_2018_Docks II. Adjust Docks and Piers to match aerial imagery a. Right-click the polygon feature layer > Toggle editing b. [Digitizing Toolbar]> Vertex tool c. Select location on the map (at 1:1000 scale) to place a vertex d. Place vertices until the feature is adequately characterized e. Right click to complete the polygon f. Delete features no longer present in aerial imagery III. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Fix Geometries IV. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Difference Input layer: Fix Geometries Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered V. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Vector Overlay>Union Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels Overlay layer: Difference XI. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Multipart to singleparts >Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels_OWS XII. Right-click Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels_OWS > Toggle editing a. Deleted all features not in the delta of interest b. Use the attributed data to label all OWS features as such in column F_Type c. Delete all columns added as a result of the Union d. QGIS Processing Toolbox> Fix Geometries e. FID column >$id f. Attribute appropriate fields Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands • ARCGIS I. Saved all Overwater Pier and Dock features in SHSTMP_PS_Marine_Over_Water_Structures_2018> SHSTMP_PS_Marine_Over_Water_Structures_2018_Docks II. Adjust Docks and Piers to match aerial imagery a. [Editor Toolbar]>Modify b. [Create Features Window] Select polygon to edit c. Right click polygon>Edit Vertices d. Select location on the map (at 1:1000 scale) to place a vertex e. Place vertices until the feature is adequately characterized f. Double click to complete the polygon g. Delete features no longer present in aerial imagery III. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Repair Geometry IV. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Symmetrical Difference Input layer: Repair Geometry Overlay layer: Restrictions_buffered XIII. Geoprocessing>[Analysis tools]> Union Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels Overlay layer: Difference XIV. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Multipart to singlepart >Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands_channels_OWS a. [Editor Toolbar]>Modify b. [Create Features Window] Select polygon to edit c. Deleted all features not in the delta of interest d. Use the attributed data to label all OWS features as such in column F_Type e. Delete all columns added as a result of the Union f. Geoprocessing>[Data Management Tools]> Repair Geometry g. FID column >$id h. Attribute appropriate fields Output layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands
(6) Attribute tidal wetland features. a. Objective. Attribute tidal wetland features with connectivity ratings. • QGIS Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands I. Right-click the polygon feature layer > Toggle editing II. Calculate Perimeter and Area for all polygons III. Identify all sliver polygons and appropriately maintain, delete if remnant of intersection, or merge with adjacent polygons less than 200 ft2 IV. Vertex tool>adjust wetland extent to match aerial imagery if clearly divergent from wetland extent V. Attribute appropriate fields • ARCGIS Input layer: Puget Sound Tidal Wetlands I. [Editor Toolbar]>Modify II. [Create Features Window] Select polygon to edit III. Right click polygon>Edit Vertices IV. Calculate Perimeter and Area for all polygons V. Identify all sliver polygons and appropriately maintain, delete if remnant of intersection, or merge with adjacent polygons less than 200 ft2 VI. Vertex tool>adjust wetland extent to match aerial imagery if clearly divergent from wetland extent VII. Attribute appropriate fields

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: DataID for PMEP layer, SHSTMP Delta Habitat feature, or SHSTMP OWS feature.

attrdomv.udom: DataID for PMEP layer, SHSTMP Delta Habitat feature, or SHSTMP OWS feature.

attr.attrdef: Unique wetland feature ID assigned to each wetland feature using the delta name and a unique number.

attrdomv.udom: Unique wetland feature ID assigned to each wetland feature using the delta name and a unique number.

attr.attrdef: Delta name derived from SHSTMP Delta boundaries and regional reviewer input.
Year the data were generated described in the regional data.

attrdomv.udom: Year the data were generated described in the regional data.

attr.attrdef: Description, other comments for external review

attrdomv.udom: Description, other comments for external review

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.
